Correlation between temperature and ƒp retrievals. The correlation coefficient was calculated using a model jovian atmosphere and is a measure of the correlation introduced by the radiative transfer model and its inversion.

ja:head.ce:title: Temperature and para hydrogen gradients on Jupiter observed from the FORCAST camera on SOFIA

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Astronomy, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853, USA

ce:list-item.ce:para: We demonstrate that useful information on latitude gradients of upper tropospheric temperature and the para hydrogen fraction ƒp can be retrieved.
An inversion algorithm is applied to measurements in three channels to obtain temperature and ƒp as functions of latitude.
Jupiter was observed on December 8, 2010 with SOFIA using the FORCAST mid-infrared camera with selected spectral channels in the 5–40 µm region.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Jupiter was observed on December 8, 2010 with SOFIA using the FORCAST mid-infrared camera with selected spectral channels in the 5–40 µm region. Although the channels were not optimized for planetary observations, we demonstrate that useful information on latitude gradients of upper tropospheric temperature and the para hydrogen fraction ƒp can be retrieved. Calibration of the data is refined using simultaneous measurements of Callisto, along with a simplified model of Callisto's thermal behavior. In this preliminary study, an inversion algorithm is applied to measurements in three channels to obtain temperature and ƒp as functions of latitude in an atmospheric layer centered near 300 mbar. The results are compared with those previously obtained from Voyager IRIS, Cassini CIRS, and ground-based measurements. The low-latitude minimum in ƒp is found to be significantly displaced northward from the equatorial minimum in temperature, unlike the gradients found in the earlier Voyager and ground-based measurements. Possible explanations for this behavior are explored.

ce:section.ce:para: The FORCAST data used in this study was acquired in December 2010. The results demonstrate that with sufficient spectral information the instrument can indeed map the para fraction within Jupiter's upper troposphere and thus can determine the pattern of a useful tracer.

Barney Conrath died in 2014 and the preparation of this report has been delayed. In the meantime, a paper by Fletcher et al. (2017) has reported the next step, which is determination of longitudinal para variations to permit comparison with the 1979 Voyager maps. Calibration and error analysis discussions are important and are treated somewhat differently in the two studies.

The purpose of the analyses described here is to demonstrate the potential usefulness of SOFIA/FORCAST camera measurements for the study of Jupiter's atmosphere as illustrated by new results on low-latitude and para hydrogen gradients. Hydrogen is the major component of the atmospheres of giant planets in the solar system, and other systems may be similar. Molecular H2 comes in two forms, para and ortho, with opposite and parallel proton spins. The molecule cannot be symmetric, since this would place the protons in the same state. For asymmetry the molecule must occupy only odd rotational states when the protons are aligned (ortho) and even states when anti-parallel (para). At low temperatures like those on the outer planets only a few of the rotational levels are occupied and consequently the exact energy values are important. The constraints cause heat capacities of the two constituents to be different by as much as 30.

The important mechanisms for conversion between ortho and para hydrogen on the planets are not known. Laboratory experiments show that the magnetic interaction during H2H2 collisions in the gas phase is extremely slow (Farkas, 1935). It establishes an important minimum to the actual rate. When scaled to jovian conditions at the observable level where the pressure is about 300mb the equilibration time constant is found to be about 108 s. The rate can be enhanced by surfaces with impurities, which can catalyze the reaction. This has led to the suggestion that cloud layers on the planets may quickly establish an equilibrium ratio of ortho to para (Massie and Hunten, 1982; Conrath and Gierasch, 1984). The high temperature (in practice T ≥ 200 K or so) thermodynamic equilibrium ratio is three ortho molecules per para, because the ortho protons with spin 1 produce a triplet ground state. At low temperatures the para molecules dominate because they can drop to the lowest rotational state and ortho cannot.

Voyager observations show global variations in the para to ortho ratio on all four of the giant planets (Conrath et al., 1998). The data refers to the few hundred millibar pressure region, and the latitudinal scale of variation is 10–20°. This height level is of particular interest because it is approximately the emission to space level. The presence of latitudinal gradients shows that whatever the equilibration time scale, it is of the correct order to match global patterns of the atmospheric dynamics, because it is neither homogenized nor in equilibrium. Thus the principal component of the outer planet atmospheres undergoes a state change near the emission to space level suitable for tracing the atmospheric advection properties. In addition, the state change involves a conversion energy that is large enough to play an important role as a ‘latent heat’ that influences meteorology.

Unfortunately observations are extremely difficult. The Voyager IRIS instrument determined global patterns on all four of the giants, but only during brief periods of closest approach during flybys. For Jupiter this represents global gradients in late 1979. Smaller scales can be discerned, but even a large structure like the Great Red Spot is not mapped in detail. The next spacecraft with the necessary infrared capability was Cassini en route to Saturn in 2001, but the flyby range was too large for useful spatial resolution. Ground-based observations are extremely difficult because of atmospheric opacity in the infrared. Recently Fletcher et al. (2009) have described an analysis program with improved retrieval techniques. If this is successful it will be extremely valuable by enabling continuous time coverage. Fletcher et al. have reported results obtained in 2009 and 2014. Our retrievals use a different reduction technique and arrive at the same latitudinal distribution as Fletcher et al. (2009, 2017).

The SOFIA aircraft operates above most of the water vapor in the Earth's atmosphere, and the FORCAST camera covers the mid-infrared band needed for retrieval of temperature and ƒp (the para fraction). In this paper we report successful retrieval of zonal mean latitude profiles of both quantities. The test flight that obtained the data was during December of 2010. It was fitted with a general set of wavelength filters not particularly optimized for ƒp retrieval and was successful in spite of this. When combined with the Voyager observations of 1979 and the Fletcher et al observations of 2000, the new retrievals from 2010 give new insight into changes of circulation patterns on Jupiter. The next section describes the SOFIA data. Section 3 presents retrieval techniques and results. Section 4 offers conjectures and interpretation.

SOFIA observed Jupiter on 2010 December 8 using FORCAST, a dual-channel mid-infrared camera operating between 5 and 40 µm (Adams et al., 2010). Data were taken at three different times: 2:05–2:45 UTC at an altitude of 12,400 m, 3:56–4:08 UTC at an altitude of 13,000 m, and 6:25–6:56 UTC at an altitude of 13,600 m. At each time interval, data were obtained with the 5.4, 11.1, 19.7, 24.2, 31.5 and 37.1 µm filters. With the exception of the 5.4 µm filter, all observations were taken with a dichroic beam splitter in the following filter pairs: 19.7 µm/37.1 µm, 24.2 µm/31.5 µm, and 11.1 µm/37.1 µm.

The technique of chopping the secondary mirror and nodding the telescope was used to remove thermal effects in the images. Each of FORCAST's two 256 × 256 arrays has a pixel scale of 0.768″ pixel–1 and a field of view 3.4′ × 3.2′. With a chopping secondary driven at 5 Hz with chop throw of 60″ and a nod throw of the telescope of 100″, Jupiter (41″.8 in diameter) was able to remain in the field of view of FORCAST for the entire length of the integration. Io and Callisto were also detected, but only appear in one or two of the four chop and nod positions. The total integration time on Jupiter after removing bad images was 165 s at 5.4 µm, 170 s at 19.7 µm, 165 s at 24 µm, 140 s at 31.5 µm, and 270 s at 37.1 µm.

The data were first processed with a general set of reduction and calibration steps designed for all FORCAST images (Herter et al., 2010). The images were rotated to orient Jupiter's North Pole upwards. Due to a short-wavelength light leak in the 24 µm filter, we used Callisto to further calibrate Jupiter. We assumed Callisto to be a blackbody with a correction applied for limb darkening. Because the Sun–Callisto–Earth angle was small during our observations, we assumed the center of Callisto to be the brightest point on the disk. In Fig. 1, we show our fit of Callisto to a central disk temperature of 175.75 K, and compare it to a pure blackbody of 154.4 K.

While Callisto was able to mitigate the light leak effect, Callisto also introduced more noise into the data: photometry of Callisto was affected by Jupiter, the background, and artifacts on the array, causing our measured fluxes to have a 1–σ variation of approximately 3–5%. Because the noisy effects on Callisto were not main contributors to noise of Jupiter, this caused the 1–σ pixel-to-pixel flux variation on Jupiter to increase from 2 to 5% after the calibration.

To have a more accurate mapping of Jupiter, we made an attempt to sharpen the images. The two major effects on image quality were pointing stability and diffraction (Herter et al., 2010). We applied a five-iteration deconvolution routine on each image of Jupiter using the MAX_LIKELIHOOD procedure provided by the Goddard IDL Astronomy Library. Since the effects of pointing stability varied significantly between exposures due to telescope vibrations, we did not adopt a standard point spread function (PSF) to deconvolve all of the images. Instead, we used the shape of Callisto that appeared alongside each exposure of Jupiter as the PSF. We show a comparison between the deconvolved images with the original in Fig. 2. We estimate the effect of the deconvolution by applying the same process on Callisto itself (a point source for FORCAST) and find improvements of approximately 30% in the Full Width Half Maximum (FWHM). We interpret this as a 30% reduction in beam width.

To extract information on jovian atmospheric parameters from FORCAST flux measurements, a radiative transfer model of Jupiter's upper troposphere and lower stratosphere is required. Given profiles of temperature T and the optically active gases in this spectral region as functions of atmospheric pressure p, the spectral radiance Iv at the top of the atmosphere can be calculated. An example of a synthetic spectrum obtained in this way for the spectral region of interest is shown in Fig. 3, where the approximate pass bands of three of the FORCAST filters are indicated. Typical jovian temperature and NH3 profiles were assumed (Conrath et al., 1998). This portion of the spectrum is dominated by the broad S(0) and S(1) collision-induced lines of molecular H2 and rotation lines of NH3. Both H2- H2 and H2He contributions to the collision-induced absorption are included in the model. The S(0) and S(1) lines result from para-para and ortho-ortho transitions respectively. As a consequence, this portion of the spectrum is sensitive to the H2ortho-para ratio, which we express in terms of the para fraction ƒp. The two limiting cases of thermal equilibrium and the “normal” high-temperature limit are shown.

In our analyses, we attempt to extract information on T and ƒp using the three channels shown in Fig. 3. The possibility of obtaining information on NH3 from the longer wavelength channels will not be considered here. To convert the measured spectral fluxes Fv to radiances at the top of Jupiter's atmosphere Iv, we used a field-of-view of 0.768″ defined by the individual pixels of he array to obtain Iv(Wcm–2ster–1/cm–1) = 2.1645 × 10–9 Fv (Jy). To correctly synthesize the FORCAST measurements, the calculated monochromatic radiance was averaged over the known total spectral response of each channel.

The sensitivity of the measurements to atmospheric temperature and para-H2 can be quantitatively evaluated by calculating the functional derivatives of the radiances with respect to T(p) and ƒp(p) as shown in Fig. 4. Since the measurements are sensitive to rather thick, overlapping atmospheric layers, we can expect to obtain information only on average values of T and ƒp. Quantitatively, this differential sensitivity is also dependent on the temperature lapse rate in the sensed portion of the atmosphere. (For example, if the atmosphere were isothermal, there would be no sensitivity.) Consequently, a third measurement, preferably with low sensitivity to ƒp is needed. The three measurements marginally satisfy the requirements for providing useful information. The analysis would be enhanced if an additional channel centered on the S(1) line were also available (Fig. 3).

The computational approach used here is an adaptation of an inversion algorithm that has been used extensively to retrieve information from planetary thermal infrared spectra obtained from Voyager IRIS and Cassini CIRS and is described in detail by Conrath et al. (1998). A similar approach has been used by Fletcher et al. (2009) for the analysis of both Cassini and ground-based thermal infrared measurements. The inversion problem is strongly “ill-posed” (Bertero and Boccacci, 1998; Craig and Brown, 1986) as are most atmospheric retrieval problems. From the many profiles that can satisfy the measurements, additional constraints must be invoked to obtain physically meaningful information. We impose low-pass Gaussian filtering constraints on the retrieved profiles with 1/e half–widths of 1.5 pressure scale heights. Since little deconvolution of the vertical profiles is possible with three measurements, this width is consistent with that of the functional derivatives in Fig. 4. Applications to simulated data calculated from assumed values of T(p) and ƒp(p) were used to characterize the retrieval algorithm and to determine the required filter strengths. The radiative transfer process and the constrained inversion algorithm can introduce correlations between the retrieved T(p) and ƒp profiles. To examine this issue, we calculate the cross-correlation coefficient to be zero, indicating complete independence of the retrieved T and ƒp. Based on Fig. 5, we choose to take the retrieved values near 300 mbar as representative of averages within the layer with minimum cross correlation.

For inversion of the FORCAST measurements, use is made of two orthogonal cuts through the averaged spectral flux arrays, one in the north-south direction along the central meridian, and one east-west along the equator. The north-south sequence can be used to retrieve zonal mean structure as a function of latitude. However near the equator the emission angle associated with the observations is near zero (normal viewing), but at higher latitudes in each hemisphere, the emission angle increases. As the emission angle increases, the peaks of the functional derivatives (Fig. 4) move upward in the atmosphere (toward lower pressures). With only three measurements available, this can result in a mixing of vertical gradients T and ƒp with true latitude gradients. We can attempt to deal with this problem to a first approximation by making use of the equatorial east-west cut through the data (Fig. 6). The average east-west fluxes should be dependent on emission angle only and represent true limb functions. It is then assumed that these limb functions are valid at all latitudes and they are used to extrapolate all fluxes to normal viewing. This can be partly justified by noting that limb functions are most sensitive to detailed thermal structure primarily at high emission angles, while in the present case we are dealing with emission angles in the range ∼ 0°–45°. Brightness temperatures from fluxes not corrected for emission angle are shown in the upper panel Fig. 7, and those based on fluxes extrapolated to normal viewing at each latitude are shown in the lower panel.

The algorithm was applied to both the flux measurements before emission angle corrections and the emission-angle-corrected fluxes. In Fig. 8, the retrieved values of T and ƒp are shown as functions of latitude for the 300 mbar level. In the upper panel of Fig. 9, the temperature retrievals from SOFIA are compared with temperature inversions of Cassini CIRS spectra obtained in 2000. The two sets of retrievals show qualitatively similar structure; however, the gradients in the FORCAST retrievals are significantly smaller. This may be in part due to the more limited spatial resolution of FORCAST. Taking into account both diffraction and telescope jitter, the effective latitude resolution on Jupiter is ∼10° near the equator, increasing to ∼15° at 45° north and south latitude. For the CIRS measurements, the latitude resolution was 5° or better.

Since it was not possible to retrieve ƒp from the Cassini CIRS spectra because the field of view (FOV) of the focal plane covering the required spectral region was too large to give adequate spatial resolution during the distant flyby of Jupiter, the FORCAST para H2 retrievals are compared in the lower panel of Fig. 9 with retrievals from Voyager IRIS data acquired in 1979 (Conrath et al., 1998). The FORCAST ƒp retrievals show a broad local minimum displaced approximately 5° northward of the equator, while the temperature structure has a local minimum essentially at the equator, consistent with thermal wind constraints. In contrast the Voyager IRIS retrievals show local minima at the equator for both ƒp and T. Fletcher et al. (2009) retrieved temperature and ƒp along with other atmospheric parameters from ground-based thermal infrared images obtained primarily from IRTF/MERLIN in 2000, close in time to the Cassini Jupiter flyby. These results show local minima in both T and ƒp near the equator, qualitatively similar to the Voyager results.

The strong hemispheric asymmetry in the retrieved ƒp relative to earlier measurements raises the possibility of artifacts that might be introduced in the analysis. The sensitivity of the measured fluxes to ƒp is substantially less than the sensitivity to temperature. The ƒp retrieval can be influenced more strongly by a number of factors including our approach to the correction for changing emission angle. The emission angle is near zero at the equator, and the µ-correction is essentially symmetric about the equator. Any errors introduced by the correction process are expected to be larger at the higher latitudes. As shown in Fig. 8, the differences between retrievals using uncorrected and µ-corrected fluxes is negligible for latitudes within ∼±15° of the equator is consistent with thermal wind considerations, supporting the correctness of the location of the data on the planet.

Three features stand out in the global structure of ƒp: a minimum at low latitudes, a slight asymmetry in the north-south profile near the equator, and oscillations of ƒp that correlate with the temperature pattern over the latitude range from about 20S to 20N. In addition, the profile of temperature with latitude is remarkably flat on the equator. This is not unexpected. The Coriolis parameter is zero on the equator, and therefore the thermal wind equation forces the temperature gradient to be zero. As remarked previously this result gives confidence that the mapping is correct.

We conjecture that the three features of the zonal mean ƒp profiles are all due to the influence of deep circulations on the stable upper troposphere. The temperature rises with increasing depth on Jupiter at all levels where the pressure is greater than about 100 mb. The equilibrium para fraction is a decreasing function of temperature. The time constants for adjustment of both quantities are about the same. The equilibrium para fraction is a function only of pressure and varies from about 0.25 to about 0.35 as the temperature drops from about 170 K–110 K. These are typical T and ƒp ranges of interest at the pressures sampled by FORCAST.

The most straightforward explanation for the global-scale low latitude minimum in the para fraction is enhanced vertical transport near the equator. This could come about by small-scale diffusive mixing or by large-scale upwelling as part of a Hadley circulation. It will be interesting to monitor the latitudinal profile of T and ƒp to discover whether the equatorial offset depends on season. Fletcher et al. (2009, 2016, 2017) have put forward the same hypothesis for the origin of latitudinal gradients.
